text: one of the hardest things about losing a
spouse is losing the one person in the
world with whom you can share anything
with when I spoke with Shirley that
night I felt that this was someone that
I could also share anything with I'm
chili Reuben Schwartz and this is the
story of how I met my husband Eric Julie
and I first met 37 years ago at Camp
Ramah in glen spey we were in touch
several times over the years either
seeing each other at you know happy
occasions in the life of this mutual
friend and sometimes satyr occasions to
when truly lost her son a few years ago
I called her to offer my condolences
after his wife died last summer i sent
him a condolence note a few months after
my wife passed away there was an article
in The Washington Jewish week about a
history conference where Shirley was
going to be speaking in Washington DC I
called her and I told her that I had
seen the article i asked her first of
all whether she would need a place to
stay overnight ended up talking for
about an hour and a half that night and
we really just spoke every night after
that it was so comfortable talking to
each other I guess because we had a
shared history and also because we had
been through similar tragic kinds of
events his wife had been sick for
several years and my husband had died
suddenly and it had been a hard time for
both of us and I guess feeling that even
in that first phone conversation we were
able to speak so deeply and candidly
about the the grief that we were feeling
and the pain that we had experienced
just it gave me such a sense of comfort
and sense of possibility sense of joy I
had a lot of mixed feelings because my
wife had just passed away and I was
still grieving but on the other hand
when I saw the article in The Washington
Jewish times to me was almost like a
sign that you know he was a person who
had been a part of my life a number of
years before then I remembered very
fondly and I thought to myself life is
too short if you think you want to call
her you should call her after talking
every day for about I guess about a week
or so I said you know I can't see for
the first time when I have to speak at a
conference so you have to come up
New York I actually had a business
meeting in New York during the interim
and I came up for the business meeting
which was in the morning and then we had
what I guess you would call our first
date we did kind of touristy things in
New York that I never really take the
time to do the 32 of courses also one of
the things we discovered we both love to
do is that New York Times crossword
puzzle so that evening that I took the
train down to DC pick me up and a
Saturday night and I being from New York
already had the puzzle so we we went to
a coffee shop and and worked on the
puzzle together that was the beginning
of november and sometime between I guess
thanksgiving and new year's we looked at
each other and we said this is going
somewhere we know where it's going and
you know that was the proposal wasn't
really proposal we just knew that this
was going to be happening but I had my
youngest daughter was in Israel for the
year we thought well we can't tell
everyone that were getting married if he
hasn't even met my daughter so we
decided to go to Israel for the weekend
and then we kind of told people slowly I
guess because there wasn't a formal
proposal I never really felt as if I was
engaged we just told people were you
married
Bernice my wife my first wife was the
love of my youth and darshan was the
love of Julie's youth and we don't
discard those memories they will always
be part of us but as we are embarking on
a new adventure together a new journey
we try to embrace that past even more
strongly because we know how important
for this to us into our families
